ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Student-led discussions
n/a

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Close reading of texts, challenging assumptions, conducting library research, writing concisely and argumentatively.
Developed a better understanding of adademic writing and was able to develop a better writing style.
I learned how to synthesize information and present it in a coherent manner.
Basics of writing
My writing improved a lot and I strengthened my analysis of readings

This course helped me develop my writing to a college level. Specifically identifying an argument and then analyzing areas where their argument falls short to identify a problem that they create. Also, using case studies to identify problems within them and building an argument as to how that problem comes about.
This class helped me to improve my skills in group discussions. I think it strengthened my active listening and response skills. I think my ability to read and break down text also improved.

I mostly gained knowledge about how to construct a persuasive argument in my essay. Some skills that the class taught that I found useful included ways to structure your thinking when starting your essay so that your essay-writing is more focused, how to determine what parts of your essay are necessary to construct your argument and which parts could be cut down, and how to draw multiple texts in your paper to support your argument.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths were that the class was well-paced, lesson plans were well-thought out, and the instructor was enthusiastic about helping students improve and develop skills.

One weakness was that this seminar seemed to have more work required of it than other ENGL 114 seminars (just based on anecdotal evidence after talking with others in different seminars).

The strength of this course was that it incorporated many different topics surrounding food politics and outside speakers were brought in to keep the class engaging. One weakeness was that some topics were covered more by the readings than others, resulting in the inability to cover many of the remaining topics on food politics.
The teacher would always ask us questions if the room was silent and he tried his best to keep us engaged. It also had a good variety of mediums we analyzed (podcasts, images, etc.).

strengths: focuses on how to write a basic and solid argument 
weaknesses: virtual format made it harder to engage and be excited about the class
Some of the articles read were very repetitive but overall gave a solid foundation for the course

This course was very helpful in improving both my writing and my way of thinking. However, it felt at times that we had too many readings and were unable to discuss them in-depth (or sometimes at all) in class. Also, many of the authors read in this class have similar perspectives and it would be nice if more authors with opposing perspectives were included. The writers' workshops were also not the most helpful and were overly detailed. They could have been more effective if feedback could have been given in-person or via zoom and the document was not as long.

I think the course was very well organized and laid out. I enjoyed the seminar and group discussions. I think there could have been slightly more focus on writing technique and less on the specific topic.

The class did teach me quite a bit about essay-writing through a trial and error process, although I sometimes felt like it was a bit difficult to fully understand the feedback given to me and how I could apply it on my next essay. Class discussions and readings were engaging, and the professor is nice and compromising. The essay prompts could be a little vague at times, sometimes leaving you a bit lost on where to start.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Virtual office hours were great. It allowed me to visit with the instructor more easily than if we had to meet in person.
Use of Perusall was a good and interactive way to share comments on readings. Use of breakout rooms for smaller discussions was also effective in keeping the class engaging.

I mean virtual engagement is almost like an oxymoron in itself so its hard to say that we engaged much virtually. That is not the teacher's fault and I think he tried to give us space to get to know each other by often putting us in breakout rooms and allowing for group projects.
Hard to have a really good discussion over Zoom
The virtual classroom via zoom was successful as were virtual office hours.
I think the course did well to adapt to covid 19 and online learning.

Online discussions in this class were pretty productive, and I do think that having open-mic Zoom calls definitely helped with that. Virtual office hours were useful but a little scarce; however, the professor is relatively easy to set an appointment up with.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if they are interested in the topic. If not, the readings may be harder to get through.
I would recommend this course for students trying to improve thier writing. The long reading combined with the writing assignment may build up to be a lot of work, but still a valuable class to take.
I would recommend this course if they are interested in how food gets to their dinner table. And if they are interested in farming, agriculture, etc.
Yes, I thought Max was a very thoughtful, understanding, and helpful teacher.
If you want to strenghten your writing skills I would recommend this course.
Yes, this course was very helpful in improving my writing and level of thinking.
Yes, I think this was a great introductory writing course and I think it strengthened my overall writing skills.

I would say yes. I definitely learned quite a bit about how to write better and I think these skills will be pretty useful in any essay-writing classes that I'll have in the future. One the other hand, if you do absolutely hate writing and want nothing to do with it, then maybe not. The class is very much focused on how to improve your essay-writing skills, and as such, much of the class builds up to your papers. I don't enjoy writing at all, but the class was still enjoyable, although I feel like it did start to lose steam towards the end of the semester (~third paper)

extras.title:
ENGL 114 06
        The Consumer Politics of Food
